title: Kettle Corn Recipe
description: This kettle corn recipe is made on the stovetop with just three ingredients and tastes deliciously old-fashioned and straight from the county fair.

Recipes Kettle Corn 4.6 (1,577) 1,286 Reviews 112 Photos Kettle corn is an old-fashioned, county fair treat. Your family will never want plain popcorn again! If you use white sugar, it will taste like popcorn balls; if you use brown sugar, it will taste like caramel corn. Submitted by Sue Cohagen Myers Updated on November 3, 2022 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 112 112 112 112 Prep Time: 5 mins Cook Time: 15 mins Total Time: 20 mins Servings: 5 Yield: 10 cups Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe Make kettle corn at home with just three easy-to-find ingredients. Sound too good to be true? It's not! This kettle corn recipe is a true crowd-pleaser. What Is Kettle Corn? Kettle corn is a type of popcorn that was traditionally made in cast iron kettles. The lightly sweetened popcorn is usually made with just oil and white sugar, but you can mix it up with sugars and sweeteners to suit your taste. Kettle Corn Ingredients These are the ingredients you'll need to make this easy kettle corn recipe: · Popcorn kernels: To make about 10 cups of kettle corn, you'll need ½ cup unpopped popcorn kernels.· Oil: A neutral oil, such as vegetable oil, gives the sugar something to stick to without imparting flavor.· Sugar: This kettle corn recipe is simply sweetened with just white sugar. Tip: To enhance the flavor, sprinkle the kettle corn with salt before serving. Jessica How to Make Kettle Corn You'll find the full, step-by-step recipe below — but here's a brief overview of what you can expect when you make this homemade kettle corn: Cook the kernels and sugar in oil over medium heat. Cover and shake frequently, then remove from heat when the popping slows. How to Store Kettle Corn Store your kettle corn in an airtight container at room temperature for up to one week. If you gift the kettle corn, make sure the container is tightly sealed so it stays fresh for as long as possible. Kristen Womack Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise "This turned out great," according to Ryan Schroeder. "I was skeptical about pouring the sugar into hot oil, but with plenty of shaking it turned out great. I added plenty of butter and salt after. Will def make again!"" "So easy to make and very quick," says L Danica. "Thanks so much, I'm so glad I gave this recipe a try. This is going to be my new method for making popcorn at home." "Who knew that you could make your own super easy, amazingly delicious and affordable kettle corn?!" asks cbailey97. "Tastes better than any store-bought brand!" Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 5 servings ¼ cup vegetable oil ½ cup unpopped popcorn kernels ¼ cup white sugar Directions Heat vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat. Stir in popcorn kernels and sugar. Cover and shake the pot constantly to prevent sugar from burning. When popping has slowed to once every 2 to 3 seconds, remove the pot from the heat and shake for a few minutes until popping stops. Pour popcorn into a large bowl and allow to cool, stirring occasionally to break up large clumps. Jessica I Made It Print 1,803 home cooks made it! Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Kettle Corn 01 of 112 Photo by  Jessica 02 of 112 Photo by  BriskRye7405 08/24/2024 Delicious! I used 1/8 c sugar w/o salt. If you like the sugar light it's a good compromise. 03 of 112 Photo by  FizzyCress4103 01/02/2024 Was easy to make 04 of 112 Photo by  NobleNaan2755 06/26/2023 Love this, so easy to make 05 of 112 Photo by  Kristy 03/22/2023 Very easy! I will no longer buy kettle corn! 06 of 112 Photo by  ashley burns 11/15/2022 07 of 112 Photo by  DapperPie5328 09/15/2022 I used a little bit of lemon extract to make lemon kettle corn 08 of 112 Photo by  BayJoe 06/08/2021 Wow, this is the real deal. 09 of 112 Photo by  reachkimo 03/15/2021 10 of 112 Photo by  Chris Windham 01/18/2021 So I made made this recipe following the ingredients list and KRISTEN's advice of shake 3 and rest 3. Perfectly popped and tastes like it came off the fairway. Definitely going to be a go-to when I have a sweet tooth again. 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love Coconut Oil Popcorn 33 Ratings Skillet-Popped Lentils with Parsley 2 Ratings Daddy's Popcorn 237 Ratings Instant Pot Popcorn 22 Ratings Gourmet Microwave Popcorn 37 Ratings Movie Star Popcorn 201 Ratings Playgroup Granola Bars 1,973 Ratings Butter Toffee Popcorn 9 Ratings Easy Cheesy Hot Dog Crescent Rolls 5 Ratings Popcorn Nachos 35 Ratings Grandpa's Popcorn Balls 188 Ratings Swedish Chocolate Balls (Chokladbollar) 10 Ratings Caramel Chocolate Corn 64 Ratings Tamagoyaki (Japanese Sweet Omelet) 9 Ratings Applesauce Oatmeal Bites 26 Ratings Spicy-Sweet Buffalo Popcorn 3 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Sue Cohagen Myers
instructions: Heat vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat. Stir in popcorn kernels and sugar.;Cover and shake the pot constantly to prevent sugar from burning. When popping has slowed to once every 2 to 3 seconds, remove the pot from the heat and shake for a few minutes until popping stops.;Pour popcorn into a large bowl and allow to cool, stirring occasionally to break up large clumps. Jessica
